text: great welcome back everybody um this is a part of a pro of the program that I have really been looking forward to uh

to hear from people who were involved uh in mit's decision to undertake its open
courseware project 10 years ago which was I think a very different uh world
than uh the world living in today um as we heard from Tim O'Reilly as we heard
from Susan hawkfield there were many influences many other movements uh toward openness on the internet and so
uh this doesn't stand on obviously um even within education there were there were other prominent projects that were
being launched uh webcast Berkeley was starting up and connections was starting up uh Wikipedia even could be considered
an uh open education Resource as well and I and certainly was getting started
about that time um but mit's announcement on April 4 2001 is probably
the clearest starting point we have of the history of uh the open courseware movement at least as uh institutional
efforts are concerned and and so we're starting with that today as the starting point of our exploration of the history
of the open courseware movement um now in my role at MIT open course whereare
uh I work with the media a lot and so I've probably told the Genesis story of open course where more than any other
person uh at MIT um but this is really sort of a unique situation for me
because I'm probably the least qualified person on the stage right now to be talking about MIT open courseware um but
I'll go ahead and give the Genesis story with all of its flaws and and probably uh Mis perceptions about how the project
got started and then let uh the gentleman on the panel correct me as we go along um but the the Legends as it
was handed down to me was that around 1999 2000 uh MIT was struggling with the question of what to do about uh
educational technology and in particular the internet a question that was ultimately handed by the Provost and the
president to a committee now one of the things that I usually leave out of this is there were actually two committees
involved one was the standing committee that was formed in 1999 called the Council on educational
technology which still meets today regularly at MIT to advise the provos and the president um that committee
handed off a number of different aspects of their charge to sub committees and one of those aspects was distance
learning or the impact of the internet on education and that was handed to a committee on lifelong learning uh in at
the beginning of the summer of the year 2000 that committee worked throughout the summer they brought in boo Allen
they brought in uh some other help and they created a bunch of business models and they looked at the question of
online learning distance education and they were really confronted with two problems one was they didn't feel like
it was a very good fit with the MIT mission to disseminate knowledge and the other was they couldn't figure out a
good way to make uh the economics of it work and so at the end of the summer they were really uh pretty convinced
that distance learning wasn't the direction to go for MIT but they really didn't have a proposal and so at that point they kind of went back to the
basics of what is the internet good at Distributing content widely and cheaply and what is MIT good at which is uh
residential education and they combin the two and said why not use the internet to distribute the materials we
create for our residential experience over openly on the internet and so uh at
least as it was told to me there was a a report that was about that thick uh that gave all the reasons why distance
learning probably wasn't going to work for MIT and on top of it was a one-page suggestion that we give away all of our
course materials so every time I speak to one
of the the gentlemen at the table or anyone else who is involved with uh the creation of open course where I learned
something new a Nuance about how open courseware came about what the circumstances were like at that point in
time uh that helps me uh inform my thinking about the core challenges that all of us face in our own open course
where how do we get and maintain uh buyin from our communities how do we recruit faculty what do you do about the
intellectual property concerns and so I'm pleased to share that opportunity for insight with the rest of the open
courseware uh Community we have with us today three of The Faculty who were involved in the proposal for open course
Weare and three of the administrators who re received and supported that proposal uh the three faculty members
are all members of our faculty advisory committee uh the first Professor Hal
ablon who also at the time of open course where's proposal chair at mit's Council and educational technology or

faculty advisory committee in addition to that we're very fortunate today to have three of the senior administrators

vest who's now the president of the National Academy of engineering and was at the time the president of MIT Dr

for sharing your time um so having given that uh account of MIT open course
where's creation I'm now going to O open the floor for rebuttal first from from
uh Dr vest by asking what was going through your mind when you first heard
what the proposal was going to be coming out of that committee well thank you very much Steve
and I'm just can't tell you how thrilled I am to have this group here and realize
we're actually celebrating uh 10 years um I I want to take very seriously the
point of this panel to give historical perspective so I could invent a very
flowery version and a very Visionary version of what happened but I want to tell you what from my point of view

last I'll find out what really did happen 10 years ago what really happened is it was a
joke but um I I want to begin by pointing out two big lessons that I take
away from this whole adventure and it is an adventure and the first lesson is one
that it reinforced dramatically which is that the really
great ideas in the University don't come from the top down they come from The
Faculty they occasionally come from the students they sometimes come from the staff but the key to doing great things
is to keeping your ear to the ground and listening because that's where the Innovation creativity generally comes
from certainly did in this case and the second thing is and it may sound a little
polanish but it also taught me in a very dramatic way that if you have a really
great idea somehow you're going to find the means and in this case the financial
means to accomplish it so with those two things in mind I want to give you two pieces of
background and then I'll very quickly tell you what my earliest experience was uh regarding ocw and its
Inception one piece of background is that uh I went to University and
graduate school in the very late 50s and early 60s and uh did my undergraduate
work in mechanical engineering at West Virginia University far removed from MIT
in many ways I did my uh doctoral work at the University of Michigan in Ann
Arbor and there was something very common to those two experiences that was
absolutely what came to mind when I first heard the uh idea of
ocw um as most of you perhaps all of you know and Susan mentioned it I believe
this morning um during World War II MIT
hosted and operated together with the British the radiation lab to develop the
British invention of radar into a real Deployable system that had a whole lot to do with the Allied victory in World
War II and when the war was over astoundingly the government shut the lab
down we never seem to stop things anymore but they closed it down and they did something really smart they gave
some of the key people involved 6 months to write up what they had learned during
that experience and what this did was create
a whole new way of bringing a basis of rational science and
first principles into how electrical engineering and ultimately more broadly
engineering was taught and practice and this launched something that is is
known in the in the trade as the engineering science Revolution and MIT
not solely but certainly was the key to this revolution in teaching and learning
in in Engineering in a very new way and how did it happen uh students were here
earning phds in various fields of Engineering in a day in which there were not many large programs of phds in in
engineering and the faculty with the follow on of this work from the rad lab and so forth were busily creating new
ways of teaching bringing first principles of Science in underneath engineering they were writing notes many
of which became uh um ultimately textbooks they were creating uh uh
experiments laboratory experiments for teaching and all these guys and I have
to admit they were mostly guys in those days uh with their freshly mined phds carried
all these notes and they went out around the country including to places like West Virginia University and the
University of Michigan and they used not a final product but they used those
notes and started adding to them subtracting from them adapting them to context and it had a really dramatic
impact first of all on me personally but much more importantly on the quality and
nature of engineering education across across the United States second piece of background and
then I'll pull this together uh many of you uh here work for various nonprofit
organizations and you all know what happens when you propose an idea to a
foundation you write them a letter or have a conversation and they say that's interesting uh uh how about a little

bear that in mind so one day and you'll hear more about it uh and Steve was was

charged and we'll tell you a lot about one day Bob came into my office and and
he said uh Chuck the uh uh committee is ready to report out their

those of you who have worked with me uh uh closely like Bob and Larry and so forth no I tend to Maul I've got to hear

instantly connected in my mind with this experience of what MIT had done for
engineering education in the late 50s and and through the 60s and I just
instantly knew this was a wonderful elegant idea and I was uh so grateful
it's nothing I would have ever thought of I'm I'm quite sure in fact as others will tell you we were really going in

Partners we work with and with very high-end students and we'd uh uh try to make money or at least least cover costs

and so u i called Bill Bowen who was uh at that time the former president of of
Princeton University and somebody I just enormously admire and he was then the
president of the melon foundation so I called up to see if I could get an appointment because I was going to be in
New York for another reason he said my schedule's busy but we'll have breakfast together so uh I met bill for breakfast
and uh a little place there not too far from melon's offices and I had a
Florentine omelet I can still remember that and I said Bill and of course I'd
really rehearsed what I wanted to say to him because I knew I didn't have much time I said Bill the faculty in MIT have
come up with an extraordinary idea and because I respect you so much as a
leader in higher education I want to know first of all do you think it's a good idea and second I want to know if

you say the answer to that is yes I'm obviously going to ask you if you think
the melon Foundation might be interested in supporting it and I then kind of laid out in just three or four or five

seen in an earlier age with these notes and experiments going out around the country but we could do it at internet
time remember that was a big phrase those days internet time and we could do it for the whole world and Bill was
silent for about half a minute and then he looked at me and he said we're going
to figure out how to do this he said it's too much for melon but I'll get my
board to agree to put some serious support in and we'll go together to heu it and we'll try to get the rest of it
so having expected that I was launching into this two-year uh business uh we got

I have to tell you something that I didn't know at the time I actually didn't know it for about 6 months after that Bill had just before this given a

you can never understand all the sort of psychological and and historical things that that go into a great great
